user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_special_api_:
```c
static int
mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_special_api_ (void)
{
  int ret = -1;
#ifdef HAVE_PSTAT_GETDYNAMIC
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    /* HP-UX things */
    struct pst_dynamic psd_data;
    memset ((void *) &psd_data, 0, sizeof (psd_data));
    if (1 == pstat_getdynamic (&psd_data, sizeof (psd_data), (size_t) 1, 0))
    {
      if (0 < psd_data.psd_proc_cnt)
        ret = (int) psd_data.psd_proc_cnt;
    }
  }
#endif /* HAVE_PSTAT_GETDYNAMIC */
#ifdef HAVE_VXCPUENABLEDGET
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    /* VxWorks */
    cpuset_t enb_set;
    enb_set = vxCpuEnabledGet ();
    /* Count set bits */
    for (ret = 0; 0 != enb_set; enb_set &= enb_set - 1)
      ++ret;
  }
#endif /* HAVE_VXCPUENABLEDGET */
#if defined(_WIN32) && ! defined (__CYGWIN__)
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    /* Native W32 */
    HMODULE k32hndl;
    k32hndl = LoadLibraryA ("kernel32.dll");
    if (NULL != k32hndl)
    {
      typedef DWORD (WINAPI *GAPC_PTR)(WORD GroupNumber);
      GAPC_PTR ptrGetActiveProcessorCount;
      /* Available on W7 or later */
      ptrGetActiveProcessorCount =
        (GAPC_PTR) (void *) GetProcAddress (k32hndl, "GetActiveProcessorCount");
      if (NULL != ptrGetActiveProcessorCount)
      {
        DWORD res;
        res = ptrGetActiveProcessorCount (ALL_PROCESSOR_GROUPS);
        ret = (int) res;
        if (res != (DWORD) ret)
          ret = -1; /* Overflow */
      }
    }
    if ((0 >= ret) && (NULL != k32hndl))
    {
      typedef void (WINAPI *GNSI_PTR)(SYSTEM_INFO *pSysInfo);
      GNSI_PTR ptrGetNativeSystemInfo;
      /* May give incorrect (low) result on versions from W7 to W11
         when more then 64 CPUs are available */
      ptrGetNativeSystemInfo =
        (GNSI_PTR) (void *) GetProcAddress (k32hndl, "GetNativeSystemInfo");
      if (NULL != ptrGetNativeSystemInfo)
      {
        SYSTEM_INFO sysInfo;

        memset ((void *) &sysInfo, 0, sizeof (sysInfo));
        ptrGetNativeSystemInfo (&sysInfo);
        ret = (int) sysInfo.dwNumberOfProcessors;
        if (sysInfo.dwNumberOfProcessors != (DWORD) ret)
          ret = -1; /* Overflow */
      }
    }
    if (NULL != k32hndl)
      FreeLibrary (k32hndl);
  }
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    /* May give incorrect (low) result on versions from W7 to W11
       when more then 64 CPUs are available */
    SYSTEM_INFO sysInfo;
    memset ((void *) &sysInfo, 0, sizeof (sysInfo));
    GetSystemInfo (&sysInfo);
    ret = (int) sysInfo.dwNumberOfProcessors;
    if (sysInfo.dwNumberOfProcessors != (DWORD) ret)
      ret = -1; /* Overflow */
  }
#endif /* _WIN32 && ! __CYGWIN__ */
  if (0 >= ret)
    return -1;
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
cpuset_t enb_set;
enb_set = vxCpuEnabledGet ();
/* Count set bits */
for (ret = 0; 0 != enb_set; enb_set &= enb_set - 1)
  ++ret;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 14.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The for loop for (ret = 0; 0 != enb_set; enb_set &= enb_set - 1) ++ret; violates Rule 14.2. ret is the loop counter (initialized in the first clause) but it is modified in the loop body (++ret) which contravenes the requirement that the loop counter shall not be modified in the body. The third clause modifies enb_set (not the loop counter) which breaches the requirement that the third clause shall modify only the loop counter. Also the second clause uses enb_set while that object is modified by the loop (third clause), violating the restriction that the second clause shall not use objects that are modified in the loop body.
